title: ‘After Yang’ Review: Greater Love Hath No Silicon
sub_head: A humanoid robot goes to work as a loving big brother to an only child adopted from China.
body:
This is a good week for new takes on older themes. In addition to “The Batman,” with its running time of 175 minutes, we have “After Yang,” a second feature by the Korean-American filmmaker who calls himself Kogonada. In a mere 96 minutes this film, playing in theaters, turns familiar tropes about machine learning into an exquisite fable that reveals its beauty slowly, almost meditatively, and ever so tenderly.
Yang (Justin H. Min) is the machine of the piece. He’d be indistinguishable from a handsome young human if he weren’t so unswervingly kind, gentle, patient, charming and devoted to the task he was purchased for—serving as a big brother to an only child who was adopted from China by overworked Western parents, and helping her connect to her Chinese heritage with a steady supply of facts that he dispenses like a post-doc Alexa. (Her name is Mika, and she’s played endearingly by 10-year-old Malea Emma Tjandrawidjaja.)
